questions.text: A 7 year old school child is diagnosed as tinea capitis. Wood’s lamp examination demonstrates a bright green fluorescence. The most likely organism isolated on fungal culture is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Microsporum canis In tinea capitis, a bright green fluorescence under Wood's lamp is characteristic of an infection caused by Microsporum canis. This species of dermatophyte produces a bright green fluorescence when exposed to ultraviolet light due to the presence of a specific pigment. Microsporum canis is one of the most common causative organisms for tinea capitis, particularly in children, and is often associated with contact with animals, especially cats and dogs. The distinctive fluorescence seen under Wood's lamp helps in early identification of the organism, which can then be confirmed by fungal culture. Incorrect Options: (A) Trichophyton tonsurans: While Trichophyton tonsurans is another common cause of tinea capitis, it does not produce a bright green fluorescence under Wood's lamp. It typically causes a more subtle presentation and does not exhibit the same distinctive fluorescence as Microsporum canis. Fungal culture would still identify Trichophyton tonsurans, but the fluorescence under Wood's lamp is a key diagnostic feature for Microsporum canis. (B) Trichophyton rubrum: Trichophyton rubrum is a dermatophyte commonly responsible for infections of the skin, nails, and feet, but it is not a typical cause of tinea capitis in children. Furthermore, Trichophyton rubrum does not exhibit a green fluorescence under Wood's lamp. This species generally presents with more subtle lesions and does not have the characteristic fluorescence that would help differentiate it from other organisms. (D) Trichophyton schoenleinii: Trichophyton schoenleinii is another species associated with tinea capitis, but it is much less common than Microsporum canis and Trichophyton tonsurans. It is typically associated with a more severe, inflammatory form of tinea capitis known as "kerion." While it may produce fungal growth on culture, it does not show the characteristic green fluorescence under Wood's lamp seen with Microsporum canis.

choices.text: Confirm the diagnosis by skin biopsy.
Do a KOH examination of scrapings

questions.text: A 30 year old lady complained of an itchy erythematous, scaly rash on face with central clearing. She was prescribed some topical steroid by a local practitioner. Now, the itching and erythema have decreased somewhat. The most correct choice is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Do a KOH examination of scrapings The description of an itchy erythematous, scaly rash with central clearing suggests a possible fungal infection such as tinea corporis (ringworm). While the topical steroid might have reduced the inflammation and erythema temporarily, it is important to confirm the diagnosis before proceeding with further treatment. A KOH (potassium hydroxide) examination of scrapings from the affected area will help confirm whether a fungal infection is present by identifying hyphae or spores under the microscope. This step is crucial because if a fungal infection is confirmed, antifungal treatment would be required, and steroids could worsen the infection by suppressing the immune response. Incorrect Options: (A) Increase the potency of steroid: Increasing the potency of the steroid would not be appropriate without first confirming the diagnosis. In fact, if the rash is caused by a fungal infection, the use of topical steroids may actually exacerbate the condition by promoting fungal growth due to immune suppression. Hence, it is essential to rule out fungal infection before considering any increase in steroid strength. (B) Confirm the diagnosis by skin biopsy: A skin biopsy is generally not needed for this presentation. A KOH examination is a much quicker, less invasive, and cost-effective way to confirm the presence of a fungal infection. Biopsy would only be considered if the diagnosis is unclear after other diagnostic tests or if the condition does not improve with standard treatments. In this case, a KOH test is the more appropriate initial step. (D) Prescribe treatment: Prescribing treatment without confirming the diagnosis can lead to improper management. For instance, if the rash is fungal in nature, using steroids could worsen the condition. Therefore, treatment should not be initiated until the diagnosis is verified, and a KOH examination is the most logical next step to determine if the rash is due to a fungal infection.

questions.text: All are effective in treatment of pityriasis versicolor, EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Oral Terbinafine Oral terbinafine is not effective in the treatment of pityriasis versicolor, which is caused by a yeast infection, specifically Malassezia species. Terbinafine is an allylamine antifungal that is effective against dermatophytes (such as those causing ringworm or onychomycosis), but it has limited activity against yeasts like Malassezia, which causes pityriasis versicolor. Therefore, it is not recommended for this condition. Incorrect Options: (A) Oral Ketoconazole: Oral ketoconazole is effective in the treatment of pityriasis versicolor. Ketoconazole is an azole antifungal that works by inhibiting the synthesis of ergosterol, a key component of fungal cell membranes, effectively treating the yeast infection caused by Malassezia. It can be used for more widespread or resistant cases of pityriasis versicolor when topical treatments fail. (B) Oral Itraconazole: Oral itraconazole is another effective treatment for pityriasis versicolor. Like other azole antifungals, itraconazole works by inhibiting the synthesis of ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane. It is often used in cases of recurrent or extensive pityriasis versicolor, where topical treatments may not suffice. (D) Oral Fluconazole: Oral fluconazole is also effective in treating pityriasis versicolor. Fluconazole, a member of the azole antifungal class, is effective against Malassezia infections and is sometimes used when topical treatments or other oral antifungals are ineffective or contraindicated. It works similarly to ketoconazole and itraconazole by inhibiting fungal cell membrane synthesis.

questions.text: Hypopigmentation in pityriasis versicolor is due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Azelaic acid The hypopigmentation in pityriasis versicolor is primarily due to azelaic acid produced by the Malassezia species that cause the infection. Azelaic acid inhibits the activity of tyrosinase, an enzyme involved in melanin production. This inhibition results in a reduction of melanin synthesis in the affected skin, leading to the characteristic hypopigmented macules seen in pityriasis versicolor. Azelaic acid also has an inhibitory effect on fungal growth, contributing to the control of the infection. As a result, the disruption of melanin synthesis is a key factor in the appearance of hypopigmented lesions in this condition. Incorrect Options: (B) Hydroquinone: Hydroquinone is a depigmenting agent commonly used in the treatment of hyperpigmentation disorders, such as melasma and age spots. It works by inhibiting melanin production but has no role in the pathogenesis of hypopigmentation in pityriasis versicolor. Hydroquinone is not involved in the hypopigmentation seen in this fungal infection, which results from a different mechanism (azelaic acid-induced tyrosinase inhibition). (C) Pteridine: Pteridine is a biochemical compound involved in various metabolic pathways, including the synthesis of certain coenzymes and pigments. However, it does not directly cause the hypopigmentation seen in pityriasis versicolor. Pteridine is not responsible for the melanin inhibition associated with the fungal infection. The hypopigmentation in pityriasis versicolor is more directly linked to azelaic acid, not pteridine. (D) Penicillin: Penicillin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections and has no role in pigmentation changes or in the pathogenesis of pityriasis versicolor. It does not affect melanin synthesis or contribute to the hypopigmentation seen in this fungal condition. The cause of hypopigmentation in pityriasis versicolor is related to fungal metabolites, particularly azelaic acid, rather than bacterial activity.

questions.text: A 15-year-old teenager has multiple, perifollicular hyperpigmented patches with scaling. Best test is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) KOH smear The most appropriate test for diagnosing a condition characterized by perifollicular hyperpigmented patches with scaling in a teenager is a KOH (potassium hydroxide) smear. This test is particularly useful for detecting fungal infections such as tinea corporis (ringworm), which commonly present with scaling, hyperpigmentation, and follicular involvement. In a KOH smear, skin scrapings are treated with KOH, which dissolves keratin and makes fungal elements, such as hyphae and spores, visible under the microscope. This is a quick, non-invasive, and effective method for diagnosing superficial fungal infections. Incorrect Options: (B) Split skin smear: A split skin smear is primarily used in the diagnosis of leprosy and epidermolysis bullosa (for identifying defects in skin adhesion). It is not useful for diagnosing fungal infections like tinea corporis, which is the likely cause of perifollicular hyperpigmented patches with scaling in this case. Therefore, it is not the best test for this clinical presentation. (C) Culture: While culture of the skin scraping can be performed to identify fungal pathogens, it is generally a more time-consuming and less immediate method than the KOH smear. In cases where a fungal infection is suspected, the KOH smear is typically the first and most efficient step. If needed, culture can be done later to confirm the specific organism, but it is not the first-line test in this scenario. (D) Biopsy: A biopsy is typically reserved for more complex or uncertain cases where there is a need to differentiate between various dermatoses, such as psoriasis, eczema, or inflammatory skin diseases. However, in a teenager with perifollicular hyperpigmented patches and scaling, the clinical presentation strongly suggests a fungal infection, making a biopsy unnecessary for an initial diagnosis. A KOH smear is more appropriate and less invasive.

questions.text: Bullous tinea pedis is most likely caused by which organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Trichophyton mentagrophytes Bullous tinea pedis, a severe form of athlete’s foot, is most commonly caused by Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This dermatophyte is a frequent cause of tinea pedis and is known to be associated with the bullous form, which presents as large, fluid-filled blisters, often in the interdigital spaces or on the dorsum of the feet. Trichophyton mentagrophytes typically causes both chronic and acute tinea pedis, and in the case of the bullous variety, it can lead to more extensive skin involvement, including vesicular or bullous lesions. Incorrect Options: (B) Trichophyton violaceum: Trichophyton violaceum is a dermatophyte that primarily causes tinea capitis (scalp ringworm) and tinea corporis. It is not typically associated with tinea pedis, especially the bullous form. While it can cause infections in different areas of the body, it does not have the same predilection for the feet or the ability to cause the blistering form of tinea pedis seen with Trichophyton mentagrophytes. (C) Trichophyton soudanese: Trichophyton soudanese is another dermatophyte, but it is much less commonly associated with tinea pedis and is primarily linked with tinea corporis or other superficial fungal infections. It does not typically cause the bullous form of tinea pedis. Therefore, it is not the most likely cause of bullous tinea pedis. (D) Trichophyton tonsurans: Trichophyton tonsurans is mainly responsible for tinea capitis (scalp ringworm) and is more common in children. It is not typically associated with tinea pedis, and especially not with the bullous form. Therefore, it is unlikely to be the cause of bullous tinea pedis.

questions.text: Favus is caused by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Trichophyton Schoenleinii Favus is a chronic, inflammatory scalp dermatophyte infection caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii. This organism is particularly associated with the development of scutula, which are yellow crusts or honeycomb-like formations that are characteristic of favus. The infection typically results in hair loss, scarring, and sometimes permanent alopecia. It is a rare form of tinea capitis, more commonly found in areas with poor hygiene or in people living in crowded conditions. Incorrect Options: (B) Trichophyton violaceum: Trichophyton violaceum is primarily responsible for tinea capitis in certain regions, particularly in parts of Africa and the Middle East. It causes a different presentation of tinea capitis, often with inflammation and hair loss but without the characteristic scutula of favus. Therefore, while it can cause scalp infections, it does not cause favus. (C) Trichophyton soudanese: Trichophyton soudanese is a dermatophyte that can cause tinea corporis and tinea capitis but is not associated with favus. It is more commonly found in tinea corporis and is not known to produce the distinctive features of favus, such as scutula or the chronic scarring seen with Trichophyton schoenleinii. (D) Trichophyton tonsurans: Trichophyton tonsurans is the most common cause of tinea capitis in North America, particularly in children. It does not cause favus, but rather leads to scalp ringworm or non-inflammatory tinea capitis. This dermatophyte typically causes patchy hair loss without the scarring and yellow crusts characteristic of favus.

questions.text: Athelete’s foot is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tinea pedis Athlete's foot is the common name for tinea pedis, a fungal infection caused by dermatophytes, typically Trichophyton, Epidermophyton, or Microsporum species. It affects the feet, particularly the interdigital spaces, and can present as itchy, scaly, and sometimes vesicular lesions. It is often caused by moisture, friction, and poor hygiene, making it common in athletes and people who wear tight shoes or frequent public showers. The infection can be contagious and spread through contact with contaminated surfaces. Incorrect Options: (B) Plantar wart: A plantar wart is a viral infection caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), not a fungal infection. It typically appears as hard, raised growths on the soles of the feet, often with a characteristic black dot in the center due to thrombosed capillaries. While both conditions affect the feet, a plantar wart is not caused by fungi, and it presents differently from tinea pedis. (C) Plantar eczema: Plantar eczema (or dyshidrotic eczema) is a type of eczema that causes itching, redness, and sometimes blisters on the soles of the feet. It is non-infectious and is related to skin barrier dysfunction or an allergic reaction. While it shares some similar symptoms (such as itching and scaling) with athlete's foot, plantar eczema is not caused by a fungal infection but by other dermatological factors. (D) Plantar psoriasis: Plantar psoriasis is a form of psoriasis that affects the soles of the feet, leading to thick, scaly, and well-defined plaques. It is an autoimmune condition and not an infectious one. Psoriasis can cause itching and scaling, but it differs from athlete's foot in terms of etiology, appearance, and underlying mechanisms.

choices.text: Potassium hydroxide preparation of the scales

questions.text: A 24 year old man had multiple small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back for last 3 months. The macules were circular, arranged around hair follicles and had coalesced to form large sheets. The surface showed fine scaling. The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Potassium hydroxide preparation of the scales The presentation of hypopigmented macules arranged around hair follicles, with fine scaling, is highly suggestive of tinea versicolor (also known as pityriasis versicolor). This fungal infection is caused by Malassezia species, and the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis is potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation of the scales. When a KOH solution is applied to scrapings from the affected skin, the fungal elements (such as yeast cells and hyphae) will be clearly visible under the microscope, confirming the diagnosis of tinea versicolor. Incorrect Options: (B) Slit smears from discrete macules: Slit smears are typically used for diagnosing conditions like leprosy, where a slit skin smear is taken to examine for acid-fast bacilli (AFB). This test is not useful for diagnosing tinea versicolor, as the cause is fungal and not bacterial. (C) Tzanck test: The Tzanck test involves scraping the base of vesicular or bullous lesions to check for multinucleated giant cells, which is indicative of herpesvirus infections (such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster). However, it is not useful for diagnosing tinea versicolor, which is caused by a fungal infection, not a viral one. (D) Skin biopsy: A skin biopsy can be used to confirm a diagnosis when there is doubt about the nature of a skin lesion, but it is not necessary for diagnosing tinea versicolor. The diagnosis is typically made through less invasive methods, such as KOH preparation, which is both quick and effective in identifying the fungal elements.

questions.text: A farmer presents with swollen feet with sinuses and discharge. The likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mycetoma The presentation of swollen feet with sinuses and discharge is highly suggestive of mycetoma, a chronic, progressive infection typically caused by fungi or bacteria. It most commonly affects the feet, especially in farmers and individuals who are frequently in contact with soil and organic matter. The condition leads to the formation of sinus tracts that drain pus or discharge and can cause deformities if untreated. Mycetoma is often caused by fungal species (e.g., Madurella species) or actinomycetes (e.g., Nocardia species), and the diagnosis is confirmed by microbiological culture and histopathology. Incorrect Options: (A) Anatomist wart: An anatomist wart is not a recognized medical term. The term may be confused with plantar warts or other types of warts, but it does not describe a condition involving swollen feet with sinuses or discharge. Warts are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and usually present as papules or nodules rather than with the symptoms of infection seen in mycetoma. (C) Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, commonly acquired through contact with contaminated plant material, like rose thorns. It typically causes nodular lesions that ulcerate over time, but it does not usually present with sinus tracts or discharge on the feet. This condition is more commonly seen on the upper limbs and is less likely to involve swelling of the feet with sinuses. (D) Plantar wart: A plantar wart is a common viral infection caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), leading to the development of raised, rough lesions on the soles of the feet. Although plantar warts can cause discomfort, they do not result in the swelling, sinus formation, or discharge seen in mycetoma. Plantar warts are also not associated with the more chronic, progressive infection characteristics of mycetoma.

questions.text: A 23 year old promiscuous male presents a week after an unprotected sexual encounter with a stranger with 2 painful ulcers over his penis with painful bubos. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Chancroid The presentation of painful ulcers on the penis accompanied by painful buboes (swollen, tender inguinal lymph nodes) is highly suggestive of chancroid, which is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) that typically causes soft, ragged ulcers with an inflamed base and surrounding erythema. The presence of painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) distinguishes it from other STIs, as this feature is particularly characteristic of chancroid. Incorrect Options: (A) Chancre: A chancre is the primary lesion of syphilis, caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. Unlike the painful ulcers seen in chancroid, a syphilitic chancre is typically painless and has a smooth, hard base. While syphilis can also cause inguinal lymphadenopathy, it is not usually associated with painful buboes. Moreover, syphilitic chancres usually appear a few weeks after exposure, unlike chancroid, which typically manifests within 3-7 days after contact. (C) LGV (Lymphogranuloma venereum): Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by certain serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis. It often presents with a small, painless genital ulcer that may go unnoticed. Painful buboes (inguinal lymphadenopathy) are characteristic of LGV as the infection progresses, but the initial ulcer in LGV is typically painless and is followed by systemic symptoms, such as fever and proctitis (rectal inflammation). In contrast, chancroid has painful ulcers and the buboes are usually the most prominent symptom. (D) Herpes: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes painful, vesicular lesions, which can ulcerate over time. Although herpes can cause painful genital ulcers, the presence of painful buboes is not a characteristic feature of HSV infections. Herpes lesions tend to be more clustered and blister-like, with painful ulcers typically not being associated with the deep, swollen lymph nodes seen in chancroid.

questions.text: A 59 yr old married male presents with recurrent itchy erythema on glans. The next step in diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) KOH smear The most appropriate next step in diagnosing recurrent itchy erythema on the glans is to perform a KOH smear. This is because the clinical presentation suggests a possible fungal infection, such as candidiasis or tinea (ringworm), which can present with erythema and itching in the genital area. A KOH smear is a simple and effective diagnostic test to identify fungal elements such as hyphae or spores from skin scrapings. KOH preparation helps to quickly confirm or exclude fungal infections, making it the best initial test in this case. Incorrect Options: (B) Tzanck preparation: A Tzanck preparation is used for diagnosing herpesvirus infections (e.g., HSV or VZV). It involves examining scraped cells from a vesicle for multinucleated giant cells. However, this is not the most appropriate test for diagnosing recurrent erythema on the glans, as the presentation does not suggest a herpes infection. Herpes lesions are typically painful and vesicular in nature, and would not be the first differential diagnosis in this case. (C) Dark ground microscopy: Dark ground microscopy is used to diagnose syphilis by identifying Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis. It is typically used in cases of chancre or secondary syphilis. However, this patient's symptoms of recurrent itchy erythema on the glans do not point toward syphilis. The lack of painless ulcers or other signs of syphilis makes dark ground microscopy less relevant here. (D) Gram-stain of scrapings: Gram-staining is primarily used to detect bacterial infections, such as bacterial vaginosis, gonorrhea, or chancroid, but it is not effective for diagnosing fungal infections like candidiasis or tinea, which are more likely in this case. Fungal infections are best evaluated with a KOH smear rather than a Gram stain, as the latter is unlikely to reveal fungal elements.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presented with painful boggy swelling of scalp, multiple sinuses with purulent discharge, easily pluckable hair and enlarged lymph nodes in occipital region. Which one of the following would be most helpful for diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) KOH mount The KOH mount is the most helpful diagnostic tool in this case because the symptoms—painful boggy swelling, sinuses with purulent discharge, easily pluckable hair, and enlarged lymph nodes—are highly suggestive of tinea capitis (fungal infection of the scalp), which is caused by dermatophytes. The KOH mount is a simple and effective test used to diagnose fungal infections. When scraping is obtained from the scalp or affected hair, KOH preparation will reveal hyphae or spores, confirming a diagnosis of tinea capitis. Incorrect Options: (B) Biopsy and culture: Although a biopsy and culture could be performed for a definitive diagnosis, it is generally not the first-line investigation for suspected tinea capitis. The KOH mount is a quicker and more direct method for identifying fungal infections, making it more appropriate in this scenario. Biopsy and culture are often reserved for cases with atypical presentations or when other diagnoses need to be excluded. (C) Bacterial culture: While bacterial infections can cause similar symptoms (e.g., abscesses and sinus tracts), the presentation described, especially the easily pluckable hair, suggests a fungal etiology like tinea capitis rather than a bacterial one. A bacterial culture would be more appropriate if there were a concern for a bacterial scalp infection like impetigo or folliculitis, but the characteristic findings here (such as hair loss and fungal involvement) suggest a fungal cause. (D) Patch test: A patch test is used to diagnose contact dermatitis or allergic reactions and is not appropriate for diagnosing a fungal infection like tinea capitis. The patient's symptoms of painful boggy swelling, sinuses, and easily pluckable hair point toward a fungal infection, which is best diagnosed with a KOH mount.

questions.text: A washerwoman presents with erosions and whitish discoloration of web spaces of toes. The diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Candidiasis The presentation of erosions and whitish discoloration of the web spaces of the toes is most consistent with candidiasis, particularly interdigital candidiasis, which commonly affects individuals who work in wet conditions, such as a washerwoman. The erythema, erosions, and whitish plaques (often due to yeast colonies) are characteristic of a superficial fungal infection caused by Candida species, which thrive in moist environments. Candidiasis can cause maceration of the skin between the toes, leading to the described symptoms. Incorrect Options: (A) Psoriasis: While psoriasis can affect the hands and feet, its typical presentation is not characterized by erosions or whitish discoloration between the toes. Instead, psoriasis usually presents with well-defined, scaly plaques that are often silvery. The erosions and discoloration in this case are more indicative of a fungal infection like candidiasis, not psoriasis. (B) Tinea pedis: Tinea pedis (also known as athlete's foot) does present with maceration and scaling between the toes, but it typically causes dry, scaly lesions rather than erosions and whitish discoloration. The skin may become red and inflamed in tinea pedis, but the white patches are more characteristic of candidiasis than tinea. Tinea pedis is often caused by dermatophytes, which differ from the yeast that causes candidiasis. (D) Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas infections are more likely to cause greenish discoloration and pus-filled lesions in cases of soft tissue infections or wound infections rather than the erosions and whitish discoloration seen in this case. Pseudomonas is often associated with infected wounds or moist areas exposed to the bacteria, but it doesn't typically present with the type of fungal infection signs observed in this case.

choices.text: Candida albicans usually causes systemic infection in immunocompetent people

questions.text: About dermatophytes all are true except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Candida albicans usually causes systemic infection in immunocompetent people The statement that Candida albicans usually causes systemic infection in immunocompetent people is incorrect. Candida albicans typically causes superficial infections, such as oral thrush, vaginal candidiasis, and cutaneous candidiasis in immunocompetent individuals. Systemic infections caused by Candida albicans are more common in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS, diabetes, or undergoing immunosuppressive treatments. Therefore, systemic candidiasis is not typical in otherwise healthy individuals. Incorrect Options: (B) Dermatophytes primarily involve stratum corneum: This statement is correct. Dermatophytes are a group of fungi that primarily infect the stratum corneum (the outermost layer of the skin). They cause superficial fungal infections, such as ringworm (tinea), athlete's foot (tinea pedis), and scalp infections (tinea capitis), by invading the keratinized tissues of the skin, hair, and nails. They do not invade deeper layers of the skin or other organs. (C) Microsporum doesn’t involve nail: This statement is correct. Microsporum species, a type of dermatophyte, primarily affect the skin and hair, but they do not typically infect the nails. On the other hand, Trichophyton species are more commonly associated with nail infections (onychomycosis). Microsporum species usually cause tinea corporis (ringworm of the body) or tinea capitis (scalp infection). (D) Epidermophyton doesn’t involve hair: This statement is correct. Epidermophyton species, another genus of dermatophytes, primarily cause infections in the skin and nails but do not commonly infect the hair. The most well-known species, Epidermophyton floccosum, is associated with tinea corporis (ringworm) and tinea cruris (jock itch) but does not typically involve hair follicles.

questions.text: Discharging sinus is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Actinomycetoma Actinomycetoma is a type of chronic, subcutaneous mycetoma caused by actinomycetes, a group of bacteria, and it is characterized by the presence of discharging sinuses. These sinuses often discharge pus containing granules that are characteristic of the infection. It typically occurs in farmers or individuals with prolonged contact with soil, and it often affects the lower extremities, especially the feet. The discharge from the sinuses is one of the hallmark features of actinomycetoma and is essential in the diagnosis. Incorrect Options: (A) Herpes: Herpes (specifically herpes simplex virus) typically presents with painful, grouped vesicles or blisters on an erythematous base, commonly affecting the lips, genital area, or skin around the eyes. The lesions often rupture, leading to the formation of erosions or ulcers, but herpes does not typically cause discharging sinuses. It is more likely to cause acute outbreaks with intermittent recurrences. (B) Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum, presents in stages. In the primary stage, a chancre (a painless ulcer) appears, usually at the site of infection. In the secondary stage, there may be mucocutaneous lesions such as maculopapular rashes or condyloma lata. Syphilis does not cause discharging sinuses, but rather ulcers and skin rashes, with the infection resolving or becoming latent without sinus formation. (D) Molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV). It presents as firm, dome-shaped papules with a central umbilication. The lesions can sometimes become inflamed and may rupture or discharge, but this discharge is typically clear or milky and not the pus seen in actinomycetoma. Molluscum contagiosum does not typically lead to discharging sinuses.

questions.text: Linear nodules are seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sporotrichosis Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii. It typically presents with linear nodules along the lymphatic system, often following the draining lymphatic channels in a sporotrichoid pattern. This is characteristic of the disease, and the nodules are usually firm and may ulcerate over time. Sporotrichosis is commonly seen in individuals with trauma or direct contact with soil or plants, especially in professions like gardening. Incorrect Options: (A) Lichen planus: Lichen planus is an inflammatory skin condition that typically presents as pruritic, purple, polygonal papules with a characteristic wickham striae (fine white lines on the surface). It does not typically present as linear nodules but rather as flat-topped papules or plaques, usually affecting the wrists, ankles, lower back, and oral mucosa. The lesions are not linear or nodular in appearance. (B) Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, scaly plaques, typically on the elbows, knees, scalp, and lower back. The lesions are usually erythematous with silver-white scales and are not typically linear nodules. Psoriasis can present with other forms like pustular psoriasis or guttate psoriasis, but the characteristic finding is not linear nodules. (C) Pemphigus: Pemphigus is a group of autoimmune blistering disorders, primarily pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. It is characterized by the formation of blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes, rather than linear nodules. The blisters are usually flaccid, and the disease involves acantholysis, leading to the separation of skin cells. Pemphigus does not typically present with linear nodules.

questions.text: Cradle cap is a type of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Seborrheic dermatitis Cradle cap is a common condition seen in infants, characterized by the presence of yellowish, greasy scales on the scalp, often accompanied by redness. It is a mild form of seborrheic dermatitis, a chronic inflammatory condition that typically affects areas of the skin with abundant sebaceous (oil) glands, such as the scalp, face, and chest. In infants, cradle cap often resolves on its own over time, but gentle washing and application of medicated shampoos or oils may be recommended to help alleviate the condition. The scales of cradle cap are thick, oily, and often appear as crusts on the scalp. Incorrect Options: (A) Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes red, scaly plaques to develop on the skin. These plaques are typically covered with silvery-white scales and often appear on the elbows, knees, and scalp. While psoriasis can affect the scalp, its presentation is different from cradle cap. Psoriasis lesions are thicker, more inflamed, and not greasy like the scales seen in cradle cap. (B) LP (Lichen Planus): Lichen planus is a type of inflammatory skin disease that causes purplish, flat-topped papules or plaques with a characteristic white lacy pattern (Wickham striae). It can affect the skin, hair, nails, and mucous membranes. Unlike cradle cap, lichen planus lesions do not typically involve the scalp in the form of greasy scales. Additionally, lichen planus is more often associated with itching and inflammation, rather than the mild, non-inflammatory nature of cradle cap. (C) Loss of hair: While hair loss can be a consequence of various skin conditions, including seborrheic dermatitis and psoriasis, cradle cap itself does not directly cause hair loss. It may cause temporary hair thinning due to the scale build-up or excessive scratching, but this is not its primary feature. Cradle cap is more characterized by scaling rather than hair loss.

questions.text: Spaghetti and meat ball appearance is seen with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pityriasis versicolor The "spaghetti and meatball" appearance refers to a specific finding in the microscopic examination of scrapings from lesions of pityriasis versicolor. Under the microscope, Malassezia species, the fungus responsible for this condition, appear as round or oval yeast cells (resembling "meatballs") and short hyphal elements (resembling "spaghetti"). This distinctive appearance is a hallmark of pityriasis versicolor and helps in confirming the diagnosis. The disease presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented patches, typically on the trunk and upper limbs, with scaling. Incorrect Options: (B) Pityriasis rosea: Pityriasis rosea is a skin condition characterized by a herald patch, followed by smaller oval lesions that often appear in a Christmas tree pattern on the back. It does not show the "spaghetti and meatball" appearance in microscopic examination. The condition is thought to be viral in origin, and the lesions typically resolve over several weeks without specific treatment. (C) Pityriasis rubra pilaris: Pityriasis rubra pilaris is a chronic skin condition characterized by erythematous, scaly, and thickened patches of skin, often with follicular hyperkeratosis. The clinical presentation can resemble psoriasis, but it does not display the "spaghetti and meatball" appearance on microscopic examination. The lesions are generally more red and scaly and do not have the characteristic fungal involvement seen in pityriasis versicolor. (D) Pityriasis lichenoides chronica: Pityriasis lichenoides chronica is a condition characterized by the appearance of small, red-brown papules that may evolve into scaly patches, often with central clearing. The disease does not show the "spaghetti and meatball" appearance, as it is not caused by a fungal infection. It is believed to have an immune-mediated or viral etiology and typically presents with discrete lesions on the trunk and limbs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with discoloration, thickening and tunneling of 2 fingernails and one toe nail. Which of the following will clinch the diagnosis at the earliest?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) KOH mount The most appropriate and earliest diagnostic test for this patient’s symptoms of discoloration, thickening, and tunneling of fingernails and toenails is a KOH (potassium hydroxide) mount. This test is used to examine scrapings from the affected nail for the presence of fungal elements, such as hyphae or spores, which are characteristic of onychomycosis. KOH preparation is a simple and rapid diagnostic tool that can help confirm if the cause of the nail changes is due to a fungal infection, making it the most useful test in this case. Incorrect Options: (A) Woods lamp: A Wood’s lamp examination is useful in diagnosing certain fungal and bacterial infections, such as tinea capitis (where it shows a green fluorescence with certain species like Microsporum canis). However, it is not commonly used to diagnose nail infections. While it can help in identifying superficial fungal infections of the skin, it does not provide direct evidence of fungal involvement in nails. Therefore, it is not the most effective or earliest diagnostic tool for this patient's presentation. (B) Gram stain: A Gram stain is used to identify bacterial infections by classifying bacteria as Gram-positive or Gram-negative based on their cell wall structure. It is not helpful in diagnosing fungal infections, such as onychomycosis, which is likely in this case. This test is more appropriate for suspected bacterial infections but not fungal nail infections. (C) Slit skin smear: A slit skin smear is a test used to diagnose leprosy by detecting acid-fast bacilli (AFB) in skin lesions, not fungal infections. This test is not relevant to the diagnosis of fungal nail infections or onychomycosis. Given the patient’s presentation, a slit skin smear would not provide any useful information.

questions.text: Which of the following are used to diagnose fungal infections
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff) The Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is a commonly used histochemical method to detect fungal infections. It stains polysaccharides in the fungal cell walls, allowing for the visualization of fungal elements under a microscope. PAS is particularly helpful in diagnosing dermatophyte infections, candidiasis, and aspergillosis, among others. It can detect both hyphae and spores, which are characteristic of fungal infections, making it the most relevant and accurate choice for diagnosing fungal infections. Incorrect Options: (B) Alizarin red: Alizarin red is a stain primarily used to detect calcium deposits in tissues, particularly in bone and calcified tissues. It is not used for identifying fungal infections and thus is not helpful in the diagnosis of fungal diseases. (C) Von-Kossa: The Von-Kossa stain is specifically used to detect calcium deposits in tissues, particularly for identifying mineralization or osteoid (bone formation). It is not used for diagnosing fungal infections. This stain is mainly used in research related to bone tissue, calcification, or mineralization processes, but not in fungal diagnosis. (D) Masson’s trichrome: Masson’s trichrome is a histological stain used to differentiate between collagen, muscle, and cytoplasm in tissue samples. It is commonly used to study fibrosis and connective tissue in diseases such as liver cirrhosis and myocardial infarction, but it is not suitable for diagnosing fungal infections. It does not specifically stain fungal organisms or provide information relevant to fungal diagnoses.

questions.text: A male child presented with swelling in the scalp for 3 months. He has a dog in the home. Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Folliculitis is a common skin condition that happens when hair follicles become inflamed. It's often caused by an infection with bacteria. At first it may look like small pimples around hair follicles.The condition can be itchy and sore. Option B-A skin abscess is a bump within or below the skin’s surface. It is usually full of pus, painful, and may feel thick and swollen. This is typically caused by a bacterial infection. Option C-Epidermoid cysts are harmless small bumps beneath the skin. They are most common on the face, neck and trunk.Epidermoid cysts are slow growing and often painless, so they rarely cause problems or need treatment. Option D-A kerion is an inflammatory, pus-filled sore (abscess) that sometimes oozes. Kerions form when our immune system overreacts to the fungal infection ringworm (tinea corporis). They most often appear on your scalp, but they may also appear on your face, neck, shoulders and upper arms.The history of dog in the home also suggests diagnosis of fungal infection.

questions.text: A patient with the ringworm infection of the scalp. On wood’s lamp examination, dermatophytic infection was suspected. Hair perforation test was positive. diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Since the patient has ringworm infection of the scalp and On wood’s lamp examination, dermatophytic infection was suspected.Hair perforation test is done to differentiate between T.mentagrophyte and T. Rubrum.Hair perforation test is positive in cases of T.mentagrophyte. Option B,C-Microsporum gypseum and Microsporum audounii can also causes tinea capitis but hair perforation test is negative in them. Option D-Epidermophyton floccosum do not affect hairs.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as nail lacquer for fungal infections?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-oral fluconazole is effective in candidal infections. Option B-topical Nystatin is applied for oral thrush. Option C-Terbinafine is given orally for onychomycosis. Option D-For Nail fungus ,different formulation of antifungals Nail lacquer are available like Ciclopirox olamine and Amorolfine.

questions.text: Identify the condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Granuloma annulare is a skin condition that causes a raised rash or bumps in a ring pattern, usually on the hands and feet. Option B-In this case,we can see an annual plaque is present wioth central clearing.If Annular plaque is present and : - Central atrophy - Lupus Vulgaris Central clearing - Tinea /dermatophtic infections Central crusting - Cutaneous Leishmaniasis Option C-Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare condition that causes large, painful sores on the skin,which can later ulcerate. The sores can develop quickly. Most often they appear on the legs. The exact causes of pyoderma gangrenosum are unknown, but it appears to be a disorder of the immune system. Option D-Ichthyosis vulgaris is an inherited or acquired skin condition that occurs when the skin doesn’t shed its dead skin cells.This causes dry, dead skin cells to accumulate in patches on the surface of the skin. It’s also known as “fish scale disease” because the dead skin accumulates in a similar pattern to a fish’s scales.

questions.text: Only dimorphic fungus which is also a subcutaneous mycosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dimorphic fungi are : -Histoplasmosis -Sporotrichosis -Coccidioidomycosis -Paracoccidiomycosis -Blastomycosis -Talaromycosis Only dimporphic fungus which causes subcutaneous Mycosis is Sporotrichosis

questions.text: A patient presented with hypopigmented macules over back and upper trunk. On KOH mount spaghetti and meat ball appearance was seen. What can be the causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given scenario is of hypopigmented macules over back and upper trunk.Spaghetti & meat ball appearance is seen on KOH mount in cases of Pityriasis versicolor,which occurs secondary to malassezia furfur.Under the wood’s lamp, it appears yellow. Option B-Tinea nigra infections can present with multiple macules that can be mottled or velvety in appearance, and may be oval or irregular in shape. Option C- Trichosporum may cause superficial infections, such as white piedra and onychomycosis. Option D-Candida can cause oral thrush.

questions.text: A patient who is a farmer/gardener by occupation, presented with the following lesion.diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Mycetoma is characterised by triad of swelling,sinuses and sulphur granules. Option B-Chromoblastomycosis presents with cauliflower like warty lesions. Option C-Sporotrichosis spreads along lymphatics. Option D-Phaeohyphomycosis can be caused by many species of dark, melanin-pigmented dematiaceous fungi including Bipolaris, Cladophialophora etc.

questions.text: A patient comes with itching in the groin since 2 months. All can cause this except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Aspergillus affects organs like nose,lung etc.skin involvement is uncommon. Option B,C,D-are the dermatophytes which affects skin. Itching in the groin indicates Dermatophytic infection in flexors –Tinea Tinea in groin is k/s Tinea cruris KOH mount will demonstrate fungal hyphae of dermatophyte Dermatophytes are : Trichophyton : affects skin, hair & nail Epidermophyton : affects skin & nail Microsporum : affects only skin & hair

questions.text: A patient presents with lesions as shown after a thorn prick. The likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given case scenario is s/o Chromoblastomycosis which is caused by phialophora verrucosa.There is h/o Thorn prick leading to subcutaneous fungal infection.The Clinical features are rough Verrucous growth.The HPE will show Copper penny bodies /Medler /muriform /sclerotic bodies. Option B-Rhinosporidiosis has mulberry like polypoidal lesions arising from mucosa such as nose. Option C-Mycetoma presents with swelling,sinuses and sulphur granules. Option D-TB can present with verrucous lesions k/s TB verrucosa cutis.

questions.text: A child comes with patchy hair loss, itching and scaling on the scalp as shown. The next best step is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Endothrix is a dermatophyte infection of the hair that invade the hair shaft and internalize into the hair cell resulting in break in hair resulting in a black dot as shown in figure.KOH mount is used to diagnose fungal infections. Option B-Giemsa staining is not used for endothrix. Option C-Biopsy is not routinely used for endothrix. Option D-Tzanck smear is made for diagnosis of herpes viruses.

questions.text: A patient presents with a bald patch on the scalp with easy pluckability of hair. Physician noticed black spots on the area. Treatment to be given will be-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Amphotericin B is a very toxic drug,hence given in life threatening situations like meningitis. Option B-Fluconazole is given for candidiasis. Option C-Black spot associated with hair loss indicates fungal infection k/s black dot/endothrix.The TOC is antifungal drug which is griseofulvin. Option D-Ciclopirox olamine is available as nail lacquer for onychomycosis.

questions.text: There is a history of prick with vegetative matter in a person after which he developed these linear lesions over his hand. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-M. Scrofuloderma causes ulcer k/s scrofuloderma. Option B-M. Ulcerans causes buruli ulcer. Option C-The given image shows Linear, sporotrichoid pattern pf spread along the lymphatics.This is seen in Sporothrix schenckii following injury with rose thorn.Mycobacterium marinum & Nocardia can also present like this in a linear lymphatic pattern. Option D-Phialophora species causes chromoblastomycosis.

questions.text: A Farmer with history of wart/cauliflower lesion on foot. Histology as shown is s/o?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Chromoblastomycosis is an infection under the skin caused by fungi. It occurs sporadically in tropical and subtropical climates, and its global incidence is unknown. The infection can be disfiguring, causing wart-like lesions of the skin which spread slowly to adjacent areas.It shows copper penny/sclerotic/medlar/muriform bodies on HPE. Option B-Budding yeast is seen in candidal infections. Option C-Broad base budding is seen in blastomycosis. Option D-Splendore hoeppli phenomenon is seen in sporotrichosis.

choices.text: Wood lamp examination showing green fluorescence
Wood lamp examination showing yellow fluorescence
Wood lamp examination showing blue fluorescence
Wood lamp examination showing coral pink fluorescence

questions.text: A 24 year old diabetic female with bilateral brown pigmentation in axilla and groin. which of the following is the correct match:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A :Wood lamp examination showing green fluorescence is seen in infection secondary to pseudomonas. Option B :Wood lamp examination showing yellow fluorescence is seen in Pityriasis versicolor Option C :Wood lamp examination showing blue fluorescence is seen in microsporum species causing T. Capitis. Option D :Wood lamp examination showing coral pink fluorescence is seen in Erythasma caused by cornyebacterium minutissimum,which presents as bilateral brown pigmentation in axilla and groin.

questions.text: A patient presents with lymphatic dissemination of his disease as shown in the picture. All the following can cause this, except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The given image shows Linear spread along lymphatics k/s sporotrichoid pattern of spread which is seen in:- A.Nocardia infection C.Sporothrix infection D. Mycobacterium marinum infection

questions.text: Match the finding of column A with best alternative in column B
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following causes infection due to bare foot walking?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Madurella Mycetoma causes infection due to bare foot walking resulting in mycetoma,characterised by swelling,sinuses and sulphur granules. Option B,C-Nocardia and Aspergillus can spread by air. Option D-Curvularia lunata is a causative agent of onychomycosis.

questions.text: Topical Antifungal used in treatment of Fungal infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Griseofulvin is oral drug for T.capitis. Option B-Tavabarole is a Topical Antifungal used in treatment of Fungal infection. Option C-Caspofungin is given as an i.v. injection. Option D-Itraconazole can be given orally.

questions.text: A Gardner who resides in sub-Himalayan area came with nodules on the forearm. What is the causative agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Sporotrichosis, caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii, is currently distributed throughout the world, especially in tropical and subtropical zones. Infection generally occurs by traumatic inoculation of soil, plants, and organic matter contaminated with the fungus.It shows rosette like condidia. Option B-Cryptococcus causes pneumonia and meningitis. Option C-Staphylococcus do not show conidia. Option D-Blastomycosis shows broad based budding.
